snippet: Germany’s devotion to the euro runs extremely deep, but there is a growing conviction that it is up to Greece to follow through on its commitments and that Europe is done negotiating.
abstract: German frustration with Greece is mounting in light of that country's inability to form a coalition government; growing consensus among Germans is that the euro zone would be better off without Greece if it cannot meet its financial obligations.

byline.original: By NICHOLAS KULISH and LIZ ALDERMAN
byline.contributor: Nicholas Kulish reported from Berlin, and Liz Alderman from Paris. Paul Geithner contributed reporting from Brussels.

lead_paragraph: Germany’s devotion to the euro runs extremely deep, but there is a growing conviction that it is up to Greece to follow through on its commitments and that Europe is done negotiating.

headline.main: German Patience With Greece on the Euro Wears Thin
headline.print_headline: German Patience With Greece on the Euro Wears Thin
